questions.text: Identify the vertebral level of section in given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T9

 

The provided image shows a cross-sectional anatomy where key structures such as the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs are visible. At the T9 vertebral level, the liver and stomach are seen prominently, with the heart also visible, indicating that the section is at the level where these thoracic and upper abdominal structures overlap. The presence of the lungs further supports that this is a thoracic level.

 

 

 

Cross sectional anatomy of ABDOMEN:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T10: While the T10 level also shows some of the same structures, the visibility and position of the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs in this image are more indicative of T9.

 

Option C. T11: At the T11 level, the kidneys start to become visible, and the heart is usually not as prominent as it is at the T9 level.

 

Option D. T12: The T12 level typically shows the kidneys more clearly and does not include as much of the heart and upper liver as seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The T9 vertebral level in cross-sectional anatomy images often shows the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs, making it a key point for identifying these structures.

choices.text: Fingers are held in mild extension
Most common involvement is index finger

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding De Quervain's tenosynovitis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It affects APL and EPB

 

De Quervain's tenosynovitis involves inflammation of the sheaths of the extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL) tendons. These tendons run side by side and are located on the radial side of the wrist, traveling through a tunnel (sheath) that can become narrowed due to the inflammation, causing pain especially with thumb and wrist movement.

 

 

Finkelstein's test: On grasping the patient's thumb and quickly abducting the hand ulnar ward, the pain over the radial styloid tip is excruciating. It's the most pathognomonic objective sign but is also seen in other conditions like radial nerve entrapment and arthritis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fingers are held in mild extension: This statement is not typically associated with De Quervain's tenosynovitis. Instead, the thumb is often held in a position of abduction away from the hand to minimize pain. The condition mainly affects the tendons and their sheaths at the base of the thumb, not the fingers.

 

Option C. Most common involvement is index finger: This is incorrect. De Quervain's tenosynovitis primarily affects the base of the thumb. While pain can radiate and might be felt in the nearby areas, including the forearm or even the index finger, the primary site of involvement is the tendons at the thumb's base, not the index finger itself.

 

Option D. Treatment is surgery: While surgery can be an option for De Quervain's tenosynovitis, it is generally considered when conservative treatments fail. Most cases of De Quervain's can be treated conservatively with methods such as: Rest and immobilization using splints, Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain and inflammation , Corticosteroid injections into the tendon sheath to reduce inflammation and Physical therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Methotrexate is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of breast cancer. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of which nucleotide? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TMP

 

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and antifolate drug that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). This enzyme is critical in the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate, a precursor needed for the de novo synthesis of thymidylate (dTMP). By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate leads to a decrease in thymine monophosphate (TMP), which is necessary for DNA synthesis and repair. This inhibition ultimately impedes the proliferation of rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, making methotrexate effective in the treatment of breast cancer and other malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AMP: Adenosine monophosphate is not directly affected by methotrexate. Methotrexate does not inhibit the synthesis of purine nucleotides like AMP.

 

Option B. CMP: Cytidine monophosphate is a pyrimidine nucleotide, but its synthesis is not directly impacted by methotrexate.

 

Option C. UMP: Uridine monophosphate is another pyrimidine nucleotide that is not directly influenced by methotrexate's mechanism of action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to a reduction in thymine monophosphate (TMP) synthesis, which is critical for DNA synthesis. This makes it effective in the treatment of cancers, including breast cancer

questions.text: A small child was playing with her maid where she rotated her by holding from arms. Immediately after, the child started crying. On examination, her forearm was pronated. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulled elbow

 

  • History of traction on elbow with forearm pronated is classical of pulled elbow.

 

PULLED ELBOW/NURSE MAID’S ELBOW

 

  • It is subluxation of radial head or more accurately subluxation of the annular (orbicular) ligament which slips up over the head of radius into the radio-capitellar joint.

 

 

  • Mechanism of Injury: Traction to elbow.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Maximum incidence in 1-4 years of age group.
    • The child holds the elbow in slight flexion with the forearm pronated.
    • X-rays are normal.
  • Treatment:
    • Reduced by flexing the elbow to 90° and rapidly and firmly rotating the forearm into full supination on outdoor basis without anaesthesia. 
    • Immobilization is not necessary.
    • Supination is a gravity-assisted movement and pulled elbow may be reduced spontaneously by gravity, but this may take time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dislocation of elbow. Elbow Dislocations in the pediatric population usually occur in older children (10-15 years) and can be associated with elbow fractures such as medial epicondyle fractures. Male: female = 3:1. Very rare in younger children < 3 years old. Mechanism of injury is fall on an outstretched hand. Symptoms include painful and swollen elbow, attempts at motion are painful and restricted. On physical examination, the elbow is held in flexion, forearm appears to be shortened from the anterior and posterior view. On palpation, distal humerus creates a fullness within the antecubital fossa. Radiographs shows loss of radiocapitellar and ulnohumeral relationship but maintained radial and ulnar relationship. Treatment is usually closed reduction and brief immobilization for 1-2 weeks. 

 

 

Option C. Fracture head of radius. Radial head fractures are common injuries and may occur in association with dislocation of the elbow. In children, radial neck fractures are more common than radial head fractures. Classically, the head of radius should not be excised in children because it will interfere with the synchronous growth of radius and ulna, producing wrist and elbow deformity. It may lead to proximal radial migration and subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint, weakness of extremity and discomfort in distal radioulnar joint with heavy activities, and may produce cubitus valgus deformity.

 

 

Option D. Fracture coronoid process. Coronoid Fractures are traumatic elbow fractures that are generally pathognomonic for an episode of elbow instability. The patient presents with elbow deformity & swelling, elbow/forearm/wrist pain. On inspection & palpation, there is varus or valgus deformity, ecchymosis & swelling, and diffuse tenderness. The treatment involves brief immobilization, followed by early range of motion. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of traction on elbow with forearm in pronation in a child < 4 years of age is a classical feature of pulled elbow.

questions.text: Which of the following defects causes familial hypercholesterolemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL receptor

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is primarily caused by a defect in the LDL receptor or Apo B100 protein. The LDL receptor plays a crucial role in the regulation of cholesterol levels in the blood by mediating the uptake of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles into cells, particularly in the liver. When the LDL receptor is defective or absent, LDL particles cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated cholesterol levels, which predispose individuals to atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease. This condition is also known as type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo E: Defects in Apo E are associated with type III hyperlipoproteinemia, not familial hypercholesterolemia. Apo E is important for the clearance of chylomicron remnants and VLDL from the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Apo CII: Apo CII is an activator of lipoprotein lipase, which is essential for the hydrolysis of triglycerides in lipoproteins. Deficiency in Apo CII leads to type I hyperlipoproteinemia (familial hyperchylomicronemia), characterized by elevated chylomicrons and triglycerides, not familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Option D. Apo B48: Apo B48 is involved in the formation and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. It is not related to the development of familial hypercholesterolemia, which involves defects in the LDL receptor or related proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is caused by a defect in the LDL receptor, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood and increased risk of atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A man wears female heels and a female dress to get sexual arousal. He is not interested in males. What is the diagnosis ? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic Fetishism

 

Transvestic Fetishism is a condition where an individual wears clothing of the opposite sex primarily to achieve sexual arousal. The key aspect of this disorder is the act of cross-dressing for the purpose of sexual gratification, not because of a desire to be of the opposite gender or any issues with gender identity. The patient described is not interested in males and is engaging in cross-dressing purely for sexual arousal, fitting the diagnosis of Transvestic Fetishism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender Dysphoria involves a conflict between an individual’s biological sex and their gender identity, such as a biologically male person identifying as female or vice versa. There is no indication in this case of any gender identity issues; the patient cross-dresses purely for sexual arousal.

 

Option C. Homosexuality: Homosexuality refers to a sexual orientation characterized by attraction to individuals of the same sex. The scenario explicitly states that the man is not interested in males, ruling out homosexuality as the correct diagnosis.

 

Option D. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is the act of gaining sexual pleasure from watching others when they are naked or engaged in sexual activity, usually without their knowledge or consent. There is no element of voyeuristic behavior described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic Fetishism is characterized by cross-dressing for sexual arousal without any associated desire to change one’s gender or sexual orientation.

questions.text: Most preferred chromatography for HbA1c? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ion-exchange chromatography

 

  • Ion-exchange chromatography is the most preferred method for HbA1c analysis that separates molecules based on their charge.
  • While it can be used for HbA1c analysis,

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrophoresis:

  • Electrophoresis is a technique that separates molecules based on their charge and size.
  • It is not the most preferred method for HbA1c analysis because it may not provide the specificity and accuracy needed for precise quantification of glycated hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Affinity chromatography:

  • Affinity chromatography separates glycated hemoglobin based on its specific affinity for a stationary phase that can selectively bind to HbA1c.

 

Option D. Immuno turbidimetry:

  • Immuno turbidimetry is a technique that measures the concentration of substances in a solution based on the degree of turbidity.
  • While it can be used for HbA1c analysis, it may not be as specific as affinity chromatography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycated hemoglobin (GHB), reported as hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), is a biochemical marker that is used routinely in the management of individuals with diabetes mellitus to monitor long-term glycemic control and assess the risk of developing complications.

 

Four basic types of methods are used most commonly to measure HbA1c: immunoassay, ion-exchange high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), boronate affinity HPLC, and enzymatic assays.

questions.text: Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pressure

 

Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by pressure.

 

  • Pacinian corpuscles (Vater-Pacini or lamellar corpuscles) are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors for vibration and deep pressure and are essential for proprioception.
  • They can be found throughout the whole body; however, it is the hands and feet where they occur most numerously and tightly grouped.
  • They are composed of a nerve ending which is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue that give it an onion-like appearance and are present in the dermis. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain: Incorrect. Pain is detected by nociceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option B. Temperature: Incorrect. Temperature is detected by thermoreceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option C. Touch: Incorrect. Touch is detected by various mechanoreceptors, including Meissner's corpuscles and Merkel discs, but Pacinian corpuscles specifically detect deep pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized mechanoreceptors that detect deep pressure and vibration, playing a crucial role in proprioception and providing sensory feedback about the physical environment.

questions.text: A lactating mother is eating only vegetables. Which nutrient deficiency will be seen in her newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12

 

Explanation: In this scenario, the lactating mother is following a plant-based diet, consuming only vegetables. Vitamin B12 is a nutrient that is not found in plant sources, making it a potential deficiency for strict vegetarians. As a result, the newborn of this mother is likely to experience a deficiency in vitamin B12.

 

While vitamin D is another nutrient that lacks plant sources, it can be synthesized in the skin through exposure to sunlight. Therefore, a deficiency in vitamin D is less likely in this case compared to vitamin B12.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) is available in various plant-based sources, such as leafy green vegetables, legumes, and whole grains. Therefore, a deficiency in vitamin B2 is less likely in this scenario.

 

Option B. Vitamin A can be obtained from plant sources in the form of provitamin A carotenoids, which are found in yellow, orange, and green leafy vegetables. As the mother is consuming vegetables, a vitamin A deficiency is less likely.

 

Option D. Iron is present in several plant-based sources, including legumes, whole grains, and leafy green vegetables. While the bioavailability of non-heme iron from plant sources is lower than heme iron from animal sources, a deficiency is less likely if the mother consumes a varied vegetable-based diet.

 

Educational Objective

 

Vitamin B12 is a nutrient that is not found in plant sources, making it a potential deficiency concern for individuals following a strict vegetarian or vegan diet, including lactating mothers and their newborns.

questions.text: Which menstrual cycle length is abnormal? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) >38 days

 

Explanation:

 

According to the latest FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) classification, the normal menstrual cycle length ranges from 24 to 38 days. A cycle length exceeding 38 days is considered abnormal and is classified as infrequent or delayed menstruation. Previously, the normal range was considered 21 to 35 days, but this has been updated to reflect a broader range of normal cycle lengths.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menstrual cycle abnormalities are categorized based on the frequency of the cycles:

 

  • Frequent cycles: Less than 24 days
  • Normal cycles: 24 to 38 days
  • Infrequent cycles: More than 38 days

 

Understanding these classifications helps in diagnosing and managing menstrual disorders effectively.

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

 

Explanation

 

In the above scenario, the patient has developed paresis (partial paralysis) but the pain sensation is intact (no numbness) suggests A fibers involvement as they carry motor, touch, and pressure sensations are most sensitive to pressure changes/compression.

 

A fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to touch, pressure, and proprioception (the sense of one's body position). C fibers, on the other hand, are unmyelinated and transmit slower pain signals. While both types of fibers can be affected by pressure, A fibers are more vulnerable to damage from sustained pressure than C fibers, which are more resistant to compression.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers. - Incorrect. C fibers are unmyelinated and relatively more resistant to pressure compared to myelinated A fibers.

 

Option B. A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers. - Not relevant to the scenario, as the issue is related to mechanical pressure, not oxygen deprivation.

 

Option D. A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers. - Also not relevant to the given scenario, focusing on hypoxia instead of the impact of mechanical pressure or compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relative susceptibility -

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with dysphagia for solid foods more than liquid for the last 3 months and has severe cachexia. What will be the best investigation to establish the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI Endoscopy with Biopsy

 

The patient's symptoms of dysphagia for solid foods more than liquids, coupled with severe cachexia, are highly suggestive of esophageal cancer.

 

Dysphagia for solids more than liquids typically indicates a structural problem in the esophagus. Upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the best initial investigation to directly visualize the esophagus and obtain tissue samples for histopathological examination to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manometry: This is used to diagnose neuromuscular disorders of the esophagus, such as achalasia, but not typically used as the first-line investigation for suspected structural problems.

 

Option C. Barium swallow: This can provide imaging of the esophagus but is not as definitive as endoscopy with biopsy for diagnosing cancer.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT): This is used for staging of cancer once the diagnosis is established but is not the primary diagnostic tool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with dysphagia predominantly for solids, especially with associated severe cachexia, upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the best investigation to establish the diagnosis, often indicating esophageal cancer.

choices.text: Pap smear
Visual inspection with iodine

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension came with post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following you will do to evaluate the cause? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial sampling

 

  • Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is a better first-line investigation since TVS is not included in the options, endometrial sampling is the next best answer.
  • Both diabetes and hypertension are risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma hence endometrial sampling would be the more appropriate test as compared to tests for cervical cancer screening.
  • Endometrial sampling is indicated in a woman with post-menopausal bleeding with the endometrial thickness is > 4 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pap smear: A pap smear should be done in all women complaining of post menopausal women with a normal looking cervix and a cervical biopsy for all women with a cervical growth but in this question, based on risk factors, we are more worried about endometrial cancer and hence endometrial sampling is a better option.

 

Option B. Visual inspection with iodine: This is not the preferred option and even if cervical cancer screening is warranted, a pap smear or HPV is better.

 

Option C. Colposcopy: This is indicated if there is any cytological abnormality on the pap smear

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Ref: Page no 560, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition.

questions.text: Which curve among the following represents the production of gamma-globin chains?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orange curve

 

In the given image, the orange curve represents the gamma-globin chain production.

 

 

Gamma globin chain is produced in the fetal period and disappears by 6 months of age. Postpartum which is the pattern represented by the orange curve.

 

The type of hemoglobin variant is determined by the combination of globin chains.

Adult hemoglobin consists of 2 alpha and 2 beta chains, whereas fetal hemoglobin is made of 2 alpha and 2 gamma-globin chains. ﻿

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Green Curve: Incorrect. The green curve represents beta-globin chain production, which increases after birth and replaces gamma-globin chains in adult hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Black Curve: Incorrect. The black curve does not accurately represent any specific globin chain production in this context.

 

Option C. Blue Curve: Incorrect. The blue curve represents epsilon-globin chain production, which occurs during the embryonic stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The orange curve in the provided image represents the production of gamma-globin chains, which are crucial during the fetal period and decline after birth as beta-globin production increases.

questions.text: All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Linea semilunaris

 

Linea semilunaris is derived from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle.

 

The linea semilunaris is a curved tendinous line located on either side of the rectus abdominis muscle, representing the lateral border where the flat abdominal muscles' aponeuroses come together.

 

It is not derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique alone. Instead, it is formed where the aponeurosis of the external oblique, the internal oblique, and the transversus abdominis meet and fuse before they envelop the rectus abdominis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal Ligament: Also known as Cooper's ligament, the pectineal ligament is a fibrous band that runs parallel and posterior to the inguinal ligament, extending from the pubic tubercle to the pectineal line of the pubis. While it is closely related to structures formed by the aponeurosis of the external oblique, it is not directly derived from it.

 

Option B. Inguinal Ligament: The inguinal ligament is directly derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. It is the inferior edge of the external oblique aponeurosis, stretching between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle. This ligament acts as a boundary between the anterior abdominal wall and the thigh, and structures like the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament in females pass beneath it to enter the inguinal canal.

 

Option C. Lacunar Ligament: Also called Gimbernat’s ligament, the lacunar ligament is a crescent-shaped fold of the aponeurosis of the external oblique that attaches to the pectineal line of the pubis. It's positioned medial to the inguinal ligament, and its formation is related to the deepening of the inguinal canal during development. It contributes to the posterior margin of the superficial inguinal ring and represents the lateral border of the femoral canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligaments derived from external oblique aponeurosis are:

questions.text: A child presents with acute respiratory distress. On examination, the abdomen was scaphoid. Which of the  following should not be performed in this patient : (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bag and mask ventilation

 

Explanation:

 

Bag and mask ventilation is typically the first step in managing respiratory distress to provide support. However, in the case of a scaphoid abdomen, which suggests the possibility of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, this method can be dangerous. It could inflate the stomach and intestines, which may be in the thoracic cavity, thus reducing lung volume further and potentially worsening respiratory distress. Therefore, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PPV with ETT: Although this can be cautiously used, it should be carefully monitored due to the risk of increasing thoracic pressure.

 

Option C. Oxygen therapy: This is a safe method to improve oxygenation without the risks associated with positive pressure ventilation.

 

Option D. Intubation: This is necessary for securing the airway and providing ventilatory support in severe respiratory distress and is safer compared to bag and mask ventilation in the context of a suspected diaphragmatic hernia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in a child with acute respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen, as it may exacerbate the condition if a congenital diaphragmatic hernia is present.

questions.text: Truck driver presents with painful genital ulcers as shown in the picture. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

Chancroid, caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, presents as painful genital ulcers. The ulcers are typically soft, with irregular borders and a base that may be covered with a gray or yellowish material. The presence of multiple, painful ulcers with some slough and pus is characteristic of chancroid. It is important to differentiate chancroid from other sexually transmitted infections that present with genital ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancre: A chancre is the primary lesion of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. It is typically a solitary, painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated margins. This does not match the description or appearance of the ulcers in this case.

 

Option C. Donovanosis: Also known as granuloma inguinale, this condition is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with painless, beefy-red granulomatous ulcers that tend to bleed easily. The ulcers in the image are not consistent with this description.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): LGV is caused by certain serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis. It typically presents with painless genital ulcers followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes). The ulcers themselves are not painful, which differentiates it from chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid is characterized by painful genital ulcers with irregular borders and a base that may be covered with slough or pus, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with the following presentation as shown in the image. Physical examination shows high riding medially rotated scapula, shaped like an equilateral triangle. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Klippel-Feil deformity

 

KLIPPEL-FEIL SYNDROME

 

  • Klippel-Feil Syndrome is congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae.
  • It presents with a classical triad of low hair line, short ‘web' neck (prominence of trapezius muscle), and limited neck motion seen in 50% cases.

 

 

  • Abnormal head position, true torticollis, and restricted range of motion, without an obvious SCM contracture is an indication for X-rays of cervical spine for evidence of cervical fusion.
  • It is associated with congenital osseous fusions (synostosis) and failure of segmentation of the cervical spine, involving two or more vertebrae. Such fusions can involve the craniocervical junction (occiput to C2), the subaxial cervical spine or both; and results from a failure of the normal division of the cervical somites during the 3rd to 8th week of embryogenesis.

 

Associated Features:

  • Scoliosis (~60%) due to fusion of cervical and cervicothoracic junction.
  • Sprengel's deformity (~50%): it is congenitally elevated or undescended scapula (Omovertebral bone bridges the cervical spine to the scapula and limits the neck and shoulder motion)
  • Webbing of neck, facial asymmetry and torticollis.
  • Radiographic findings of congenital cervical vertebral fusion are diagnostic.
  • Neurological sequelae due to involvement of brain stem or cervical cord may be present.
  • Syndactyly and diffuse or focal upper extremity hypoplasia.
  • Secondary osteoarthritis, disc degeneration, spinal stenosis.
  • Genito-renal anomalies (~35%, so USG is recommended)
  • Congenital heart defects (~15%, so ECHO is recommended)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sprengel’s deformity. It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect. The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position. Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue. From the superior angle of scapula, a sheet or band like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae, known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

Option B. Separated shoulder deformity. A shoulder separation is not truly an injury to the shoulder joint. The injury actually involves the acromioclavicular joint. The most common cause for a separation of the AC joint is from a fall directly onto the shoulder, injuring the ligaments around the AC joint. If the force is severe enough, the ligaments attaching to the underside of the clavicle are torn, causing the separation of the clavivle and the scapula. The scapula moves downward from the weight of the arm, creating a bump or bulge above the shoulder.

 

 

Option C. Torticollis. Torticollis is a symptom of cervical spine abnormality. Congenital torticollis is due to fibrosis of sternocleidomastoid muscle on one side that fails to elongate as child grows. The cause is muscle ischemia from a distorted position in utero (breech) or birth injury. A history of difficult labour followed by lump over SCM (sternomastoid tumor) in first few weeks of life, which disappears in few months is present. Then, there is neither deformity nor obvious limitation of movements. Deformity does not become apparent until the child is 1-2 years old. SCM on involved side may feel tight and hard and a mass or knot can be detected in the body of SCM. It can disappear spontaneously. There may be asymmetrical development of face (plagiocephaly).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High riding medially rotated scapula, shaped like an equilateral triangle is seen in Klippel-Feil syndrome. This occurs due to congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae in the craniocervical junction and/or subaxial cervical spine.

questions.text: The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Y chromosome

 

Explanation:

 

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, specifically the SRY gene located on the short arm of the Y chromosome. The SRY gene produces testis-determining factor (TDF), which induces the development of the bipotential gonads into testes. The Sertoli cells in the testes secrete Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH), which causes regression of the Mullerian ducts, structures that would otherwise develop into female internal genitalia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, specifically the SRY gene, which leads to the secretion of Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) by the Sertoli cells and regression of the Mullerian ducts in males.

questions.text: Identify the image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroid


The image shows a well-circumscribed, whitish lesion within the uterine cavity, which is characteristic of a submucosal fibroid. Fibroids, also known as leiomyomas, are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus. They can present as distinct, well-defined lesions that are separate from the normal myometrial tissue, often appearing white or light in color compared to the surrounding pink myometrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Adenomyosis:  is incorrect because adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium, leading to a uniformly enlarged and diffusely thickened uterus without distinct, well-defined lesions.

 

Option C. Endometrial polyp:  is incorrect as polyps are usually small, soft, and protruding growths that arise from the endometrial lining. They do not appear as a well-defined, firm, and large mass like the fibroid shown.

 

Option D. Endometrial cancer: is incorrect because endometrial cancer typically presents as irregular, vascular, and possibly friable growths within the uterine cavity, not as a smooth, well-defined mass.

 

Educational Objective:


Fibroids are well-defined, circumscribed lesions within the uterine cavity that are distinct in color and structure compared to surrounding myometrial tissue, distinguishing them from other uterine conditions like adenomyosis, polyps, and cancer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with weakness and fatigue. Lab reports showed low Hb and high reticulocyte count. WBC and platelet counts were normal. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemolytic anemia

 

The presence of a high reticulocyte count in the context of anemia indicates that the bone marrow is responding appropriately by producing more red blood cells to compensate for the anemia. This is a typical finding in hemolytic anemia, where there is increased destruction of red blood cells in the periphery, leading to an increase in reticulocyte production as the bone marrow attempts to replace the lost cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia of chronic disease: This type of anemia is typically characterized by a low reticulocyte count due to impaired erythropoiesis in response to chronic inflammation or disease.

 

Option B. Aplastic crisis: In aplastic crisis, there is a failure of the bone marrow to produce sufficient blood cells, leading to low reticulocyte counts, along with low white blood cell and platelet counts.

 

Option D. Pernicious anemia: This is caused by vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to impaired DNA synthesis and resulting in megaloblastic anemia. It typically presents with low reticulocyte counts and can also affect white blood cells and platelets, causing pancytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of anemia with a high reticulocyte count and normal white blood cell and platelet counts, hemolytic anemia is the likely diagnosis, indicating increased peripheral destruction of red blood cells and a compensatory increase in reticulocyte production by the bone marrow.

choices.text: Age 6 months – 5 years
Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes
No need for long term antiepileptics

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about febrile seizure?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 54% recurrence

 

Febrile seizures are convulsions brought on by a fever in infants or small children. They are relatively common and typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years. The main features of febrile seizures include:

 

  • Age 6 months – 5 years: This is the typical age range for febrile seizures, making this statement true.
  • Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes: Simple febrile seizures are brief, usually lasting less than 15 minutes. This statement is also true.
  • No need for long term antiepileptic: In the case of simple febrile seizures, long-term antiepileptic treatment is generally not necessary. This statement is true as well.

 

The statement "54% recurrence" is not true. The recurrence rate for febrile seizures is significantly lower. While there is a risk of recurrence, it is not as high as 54%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Febrile seizures typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years, last less than 15 minutes, and do not require long-term antiepileptic treatment. The recurrence rate is much lower than 54%.

questions.text: A person who has undergone a bone marrow transplant in the past is now presenting with a lung lesion. Upon microscopic analysis, the image of the lesion is provided below. What is the probable responsible organism for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mucormycosis

 

Explanation:

 

Mucormycosis is indicated in this clinical scenario due to the patient's history of a bone marrow transplant and the presence of a lung lesion. The image provided shows broad aseptate hyphae , which is characteristic of Mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histoplasma: Is a dimorphic fungus. At 25°C, it shows mycelial phase and at 37°C, it shows Yeast form.

 

 

Option B. Cryptococcus: Colonies can be demonstrated by negative staining of their capsule.

 

 

Option D. Aspergillosis: Shows narrow, acute angled branching and septate, differing from the non-septate hyphae

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis  is characterized broad aseptate hyphae with acute -angle branching. which commonly affecting in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Thrombosis is initiated by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endothelial injury

 

Thrombosis is initiated by endothelial injury.

 

Thrombosis is the formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel, obstructing the flow of blood through the circulatory system.

 


 

Three primary abnormalities, known as the Virchow triad, are known to cause thrombosis.

 

They include:

 

  • Endothelial injury - most important factor
  • Stasis or turbulent blood flow
  • Hypercoagulability of the blood

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet activation: While platelet activation is a crucial step in the formation of a thrombus, it is typically initiated by endothelial injury, making endothelial injury the primary initiating event.

 

Option C. Coagulation cascade: The coagulation cascade is activated following endothelial injury and platelet activation, but it is not the initiating event of thrombosis.

 

Option D. Vasoconstriction of vessels: Vasoconstriction occurs as a response to endothelial injury and helps limit blood flow to the site of injury, but it is not the initiating factor in thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombosis is primarily initiated by endothelial injury, which is a key component of the Virchow triad and leads to the subsequent activation of platelets and the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is/are true about Crohn’s disease, in contrast to ulcerative colitis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More risk of perianal fistulae

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), but they have distinct characteristics and should not be considered the same. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, and is known for causing "skip lesions," meaning areas of diseased tissue interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

  • Perianal fistulae: Crohn’s disease is more associated with perianal complications, including fistulae, abscesses, and fissures, due to the deeper transmural inflammation that characterizes the disease. This is in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which primarily involves the mucosa and submucosa and starts from the rectum, rarely involving perianal areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesions are continuous: This statement is incorrect for Crohn’s disease. Continuous lesions are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. In Crohn’s disease, the inflammation is patchy, with skip lesions being typical.

 

Option C. Malignancy is more common: Malignancy is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis, particularly colorectal cancer, due to the long-standing inflammation typically confined to the colon. Crohn’s disease has a lower risk of malignancy.

 

Option D. Often presents with hematochezia: Hematochezia, or the passage of fresh blood in the stool, is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis. Crohn’s disease typically presents with non-bloody diarrhea, although some cases might involve blood, it is not as frequent as in ulcerative colitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crohn’s disease is characterized by a higher risk of perianal fistulae and skip lesions, in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which presents with continuous lesions and a higher risk of colorectal malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Klumpke’s palsy?(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Claw hand

 

  • Klumpke’s palsy is the lower brachial plexus injury involving C8 and T1 nerve roots.
  • It is less common, but more severe.
  • It involves weakness of wrist and finger flexors and the intrinsic hand muscles.
  • Sensation is lost on ulnar side of the forearm.
  • There may also be vasomotor impairment and unilateral Horner’s syndrome.
  • Claw hand deformity is the usual outcome.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wrist drop. The radial nerve is responsible for innervating the extensor muscles of the wrist and digits. Consequently, injury to the radial nerve results in the inability to properly utilize these extensor muscles. As a result, the hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position. This is known as wrist drop.

 

 

Option B. Ape thumb deformity. Ape thumb deformity is a condition in which the thumb is permanently rotated and adducted, resulting in a loss of its opposable function. This deformity is caused by damage to the distal median nerve, which supplies the muscles that control the thumb. The thumb may also experience limited flexion and extension.

 

 

Option D. Porter’s tip deformity. Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (mainly C5, partially C6) causes Erb's Paralysis. This causes paralysis of biceps, deltoid, brachialis and brachioradialis mainly; and supraspinatus, infraspinatus, supinator partially. The muscle paralysis causes the arm to hang by the side in adduction and medial rotation with forearm extended and pronated. This deformity is called as “policeman’s tip” or “porter’s tip hand”.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The characteristic deformity of Klumpke’s palsy is Claw hand due to paralysis of intrinsic hand muscles and weakness of wrist and finger flexors.

questions.text: The most common cancer found among the female population in India is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Breast cancer

 

In India, breast cancer is the most common cancer affecting the female population.

 

It ranks highest in terms of incidence, prevalence, and mortality among cancers in women.

 

Breast cancer has overtaken cervical cancer, which used to be the leading cause of cancer-related morbidity among Indian women. This shift reflects changes in lifestyle, reproductive patterns, and awareness.

 

Statistically, breast cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths among Indian women, and its incidence continues to rise, making it a significant public health concern. Additionally, breast cancer is also the most common cancer when considering the total population (both male and female) combined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral and lip cancer: While oral and lip cancers are common in India, particularly due to tobacco use, they are more prevalent in males and do not surpass breast cancer in females in terms of incidence.

 

Option B. Cervical cancer: Cervical cancer was previously the most common cancer among women in India. However, breast cancer has now overtaken it in terms of both incidence and mortality.

 

Option D. Lung cancer: Lung cancer, while common, is more prevalent in males. It is not the most common cancer among females in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among the female population in India, leading in incidence, prevalence, and mortality rates. Followed by cervico-uterine cancer, ovarian cancer, lip and oral cavity cancer, and colorectal cancer, respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following rules out transudative pleural effusion except? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High fibrin

 

Explanation:

 

Transudative pleural effusions are typically characterized by low protein, low specific gravity, and low cellular content. High fibrin content, on the other hand, is suggestive of an exudative effusion rather than a transudative one.

 

Differentiating features:

 

 

 

Additional information

 

Light's criteria: These are used to differentiate exudative pleural effusions from transudative effusions based on the chemical and cellular characteristics of the pleural fluid.

 

  1. Protein Ratio: If the ratio of the protein content in the pleural effusion to the serum protein is more than 0.5 (or 50%), the effusion is likely an exudate.
  2. LDH Ratio: If the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level in the effusion is more than 60% (or 0.6) of the serum LDH, it indicates that the effusion is likely an exudate.
  3. LDH Upper Limit: If the LDH level in the effusion exceeds two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH as defined by the laboratory, the effusion is likely an exudate.

 

If, any one out of three criteria is positive, then its an exudate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low protein: This is a feature of transudative effusions.

 

Option C. Low specific gravity: This is also a characteristic of transudative effusions.

 

Option D. Low cellular content: This is another feature seen in transudative effusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High fibrin content in pleural fluid is indicative of an exudative effusion, which rules out the diagnosis of a transudative pleural effusion.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with painless, massive lower gastrointestinal bleeding. He is diagnosed with Meckel's diverticulum, and surgical treatment is planned. Which of the following is the most commonly encountered ectopic tissue in Meckel's diverticulum? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastric and pancreatic

 

Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital anomaly caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct during gestation. The rule of 2s mnemonic for Meckel's diverticulum includes 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric and pancreatic), located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve, approximately 2 inches in length, and with a 2% incidence.

 

Meckel's diverticulum can present with painless, massive lower gastrointestinal bleeding, and it can be a lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception. Diagnosis is confirmed with a 99mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect gastric mucosa and pancreatic tissue.

 

Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel's diverticulum, and V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is commonly performed.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with fever and lymph node enlargement whose tissue biopsy image is provided here? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

The biopsy image provided shows the characteristic features of a granulomatous inflammation with the presence of Langhans giant cells. Langhans giant cells are multinucleated cells formed by the fusion of macrophages, and they are commonly seen in granulomas associated with tuberculosis. These cells have a distinctive arrangement of nuclei in a horseshoe or ring shape, which is a hallmark of tubercular granulomas.

 

In this clinical scenario, the patient presents with fever and lymph node enlargement (lymphadenopathy), which, along with the biopsy findings, strongly suggests a diagnosis of tuberculosis. Tuberculosis is a common cause of granulomatous inflammation, particularly in regions where the disease is endemic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hodgkin lymphoma: This is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, which have a distinctive "owl's eye" appearance. These cells are not present in the biopsy image provided.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis also causes granulomatous inflammation but typically does not show caseation necrosis or Langhans giant cells. Non-caseating granulomas are more typical of sarcoidosis.

 

Option D. Secondaries: This refers to metastatic cancer involving the lymph nodes. The biopsy image does not show the characteristic features of metastatic cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langhans giant cells, with their horseshoe-shaped nuclei, are a characteristic finding in granulomas associated with tuberculosis, making this the most likely diagnosis in a patient with fever and lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: During climbing the staircase, a person suddenly fell & a sharp object hit on his neck. After the injury, the patient is unable to shrug/elevate the shoulder & he is having difficulty in turning his head. What structure is most likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spinal accessory nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The spinal accessory nerve (11th cranial nerve) innervates both the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. The trapezius muscle is responsible for the elevation or shrugging of the shoulder, while the sternocleidomastoid muscle is responsible for turning the head. Injury to the spinal accessory nerve results in an inability to perform these actions, which matches the patient's symptoms of being unable to shrug/elevate the shoulder and having difficulty turning the head. Therefore, the most likely structure damaged in this case is the spinal accessory nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is responsible for the protraction and upward rotation of the scapula. Damage to this nerve causes winging of the scapula, not an inability to shrug the shoulder or turn the head.

 

Option C. Sternocleidomastoid: While the sternocleidomastoid muscle is indeed involved in turning the head, its dysfunction alone would not explain the inability to shrug the shoulder. The issue lies with the nerve that innervates both the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Option D. Deltoid: This muscle is innervated by the axillary nerve and is responsible for shoulder abduction. Damage to the deltoid or axillary nerve would cause difficulty in shoulder abduction, not in shrugging the shoulder or turning the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal accessory nerve (11th cranial nerve) is responsible for innervating the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles, which are essential for shrugging the shoulder and turning the head, respectively.

choices.text: Lyophylised Amphotericin B

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Voriconazole

 

Voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. It can also be used against candida species (including glabrata and krusei), scedosporium and fusarium.

 

The other options can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole: While effective against Aspergillus species, itraconazole is generally considered less effective than voriconazole for invasive cases due to its variable bioavailability and slower onset of action.

 

Option C. Lyophylised Amphotericin B: Often used as a second-line treatment or in patients who cannot tolerate azole antifungals. It has a broader spectrum but is also associated with more severe side effects, particularly nephrotoxicity.

 

Option D. Posaconazole: This is another alternative, especially for prophylaxis against Aspergillus in high-risk patients, but it is generally used when voriconazole is contraindicated or not tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Voriconazole's effectiveness, broad spectrum of activity, and favorable pharmacokinetic profile make it the first-line treatment for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, offering significant benefits in terms of efficacy and patient outcomes in severe fungal infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for splenectomy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

 

Bone marrow failure is not an indication for splenectomy because removing the spleen does not address the underlying cause of bone marrow failure. Splenectomy would not provide any benefit in managing or treating bone marrow failure, as the problem lies within the bone marrow's ability to produce blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iatrogenic splenic rupture: This refers to a rupture of the spleen caused inadvertently by medical intervention. In cases of splenic rupture, splenectomy is often necessary to prevent further complications such as internal bleeding.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: Splenectomy can be indicated for thrombocytopenia, particularly if it is caused by conditions like Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP), where the spleen destroys platelets.

 

Option C. Splenic infarct with sepsis: In cases where a splenic infarct leads to sepsis, splenectomy may be necessary to remove the infected spleen and control the spread of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bone marrow failure is not an indication for splenectomy, as the procedure does not address the underlying pathology of bone marrow production issues.

questions.text: A 2 month pregnant female presents with swelling in legs and diagnosed with Deep vein thrombosis, she requires anticoagulation. Which of the following is Preferred?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enoxaparin

 

Explanation

 

In pregnant women diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) such as enoxaparin is the preferred anticoagulant.

 

LMWH is effective and has a better safety profile for both the mother and the fetus compared to other anticoagulants.

 

Warfarin is teratogenic and contraindicated in pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester. Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) like apixaban are not recommended during pregnancy due to insufficient safety data. Aspirin alone is not effective for treating DVT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: This is contraindicated during pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects.

 

Option B. Apixaban: DOACs are not approved for use in pregnant or lactating women due to a lack of sufficient safety data.

 

Option D. Aspirin: While it may be used for certain cardiovascular conditions, it is not effective as a sole agent for the treatment of DVT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enoxaparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for pregnant women with DVT due to its safety and effectiveness, whereas warfarin, DOACs, and aspirin are not appropriate choices in this context.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding audit in obstetrics? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Done before analysing outcomes

 

Clinical audit in obstetrics is a method performed to ensure that healthcare provisions are standardized and consistently improved in line with evidence-based practice. The purpose of an obstetrics audit is to analyze the current level of care and identify areas for improvement. Therefore, it is typically conducted after analyzing outcomes to assess and enhance the quality of care provided. This helps in determining whether the current practices are effective or if changes are needed to improve patient outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Improve treatment: This statement is true as clinical audits aim to improve treatment by identifying gaps in current practices and implementing evidence-based solutions to enhance patient care.

 

Option B. Fetal death rate analysis: This is also true. Clinical audits often include analyzing fetal death rates to understand the causes and contributing factors, which can lead to improved strategies to reduce such occurrences.

 

Option C. Improving hospital administration: This statement is correct. Audits can identify administrative issues that affect patient care, thereby helping to streamline processes and improve overall hospital administration and efficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical audits in obstetrics are conducted after analyzing outcomes to ensure that healthcare provisions are standardized and continuously improved based on evidence-based practices.

 

Ref: Dutta textbook of Obstetrics page728-729

choices.text: To prevent teratogenic effects
To avoid failure of ATT
Because rifampicin can decrease OCP metabolism
Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with tuberculosis and is about to begin antitubercular therapy (ATT) that includes rifampicin. She is currently taking oral contraceptives (OCP) for birth control. The clinician advises her to use an additional barrier method of contraception while undergoing treatment. What is the primary reason for this recommendation? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure

 

Rifampicin is used as one of the first line drugs against tuberculosis. Rifampicin is an enzyme inducer, that induces the cytochrome P450 enzymes. Therefore, this leads to increased rate of metabolism of the OCPs, thereby leading to contraceptive failure. So, in a female receiving ATT, it is advised to use additional barrier methods of contraception apart from OCPs.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. To prevent teratogenic effects: Most of the antitubercular drugs including rifampicin, isoniazid and ethambutol are safe in pregnancy. Further she is already taking OCPs, so the examiner does not want to ask about teratogenic effect of antitubercular drugs.

 

Option B. To avoid failure of ATT: The interaction between ATT and OCP does not lead to the failure of antitubercular therapy; rather, it affects the efficacy of the oral contraceptive method.

 

Option C. Because rifampicin can decrease OCP metabolism: This is incorrect because rifampicin actually induces, rather than decreases, the metabolism of oral contraceptives. This can lead to reduced levels of contraceptive hormones in the blood, thereby potentially leading to contraceptive failure.

 

Educational Objective

 

Rifampicin is known to induce hepatic enzymes that speed up the metabolism of various drugs, including oral contraceptives. This can lead to lower blood levels of the hormones in OCPs, thereby reducing their efficacy and increasing the risk of contraceptive failure. Hence, it is advised for patients on both medications to use an additional barrier method of contraception.

questions.text: A 19-year-old youth was brought the casualty with a black eye following a fist fight. Which area of the orbit is most likely to have been fractured? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Floor

 

  • The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the floor of the orbit.
  • BLOW-out fractures involve LOW wall (means inferior wall or floor of orbit).
  • The floor consists of three bones: the zygomatic, maxillary, and palatine bones. The posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone is relatively weak and may be involved in a "blowout" fracture.
  • Clinical features:
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • Positive “forced duction test”
  • Management:
  • X ray (Waters view) and CT-Scan of orbit show tear drop sign.
  • Conservative management may be useful in a good number of patients.
  • However, surgical intervention if required should be done about 2 weeks of injury with synthetic material like supramide, teflon or silicon.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial wall: Less commonly involved in isolated blowout fractures; can be associated with subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Option B. Lateral wall: The strongest wall of the orbit and less likely to fracture in isolated blunt trauma.

 

Option C. Roof: More common in children due to its thinness but less common overall compared to the floor in blowout fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The floor of the orbit is the most likely site of fracture in cases of orbital blowout fractures resulting from blunt trauma, such as a fist fight. Key clinical features include enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. Imaging with X-rays and CT scans are crucial for diagnosis and surgical intervention may be required for severe cases.

questions.text: The patient has a fever, cough, and cold. The chest X-ray is given below. What will be the examination finding in the infra-scapular region? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dull note on percussion

 

The patient's symptoms and the chest X-ray findings indicate pleural effusion. Key features of pleural effusion on a chest X-ray include the meniscus sign and blunting of the costophrenic angle. Clinically, pleural effusion leads to reduced or absent air entry in the affected area.

 

A dull note on percussion is a hallmark sign of pleural effusion. This occurs due to the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, which does not transmit sound vibrations as efficiently as air-filled lung tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperresonance on percussion: This finding is characteristic of pneumothorax, where there is an excess of air in the pleural space, leading to increased resonance.

 

Option B. Coarse crackles: Coarse crackles can be heard in various conditions such as bronchiectasis, the resolving phase of pneumonia, or pulmonary edema. However, they are not typically associated with pleural effusion.

 

Option D. Pleural rub: Pleural rub is a sign of pleuritis or inflammation of the pleura. It is usually absent in pleural effusion due to the separation of pleural surfaces by fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dull note on percussion is a key clinical finding in pleural effusion, indicating the presence of fluid in the pleural space.

questions.text: Which infection contracted in pregnancy won't be teratogenic?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV 2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV 2) primarily causes genital infections and is not generally teratogenic. It poses risks primarily at delivery if there is an active infection, leading to neonatal herpes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella: Rubella is highly teratogenic, especially if contracted in the first trimester.

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common cause of congenital infections and can result in severe fetal abnormalities.

 

Option D. Chicken pox: Chickenpox (Varicella) can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which is teratogenic.

 

Educational objective:

 

Among the listed infections, HSV 2 is not considered teratogenic, although it requires careful management to prevent neonatal transmission during delivery.

questions.text: In primary accidental hypothermia, what is the usual rate of rewarming with passive external rewarming?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.5-2°C per hour

 

Explanation

 

Primary accidental hypothermia refers to an unintentional drop in core body temperature due to environmental exposure. The management of hypothermia includes rewarming strategies, which can be classified into passive and active rewarming.

 

Passive External Rewarming: This method involves insulating the patient by covering them with blankets and ensuring that the head is also covered. It relies on the patient's own heat production to gradually increase body temperature.

 

According to standard medical guidelines and Harrison's principles, passive external rewarming can increase the core body temperature by approximately 0.5 to 2°C per hour.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In cases of primary accidental hypothermia, passive external rewarming can raise the core body temperature by 0.5 to 2°C per hour.

 

Additional Information –

 

Hypothermia based on core body temperature and corresponding treatment methods:

 

  1. Mild Hypothermia:
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 35 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Passive external rewarming is the treatment of choice.
  2. Moderate Hypothermia:
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 32 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Requires both passive and active rewarming methods. Passive rewarming involves external methods, while active rewarming can be either external or internal.
  3. Severe Hypothermia
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 28 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Requires both passive and active rewarming methods. Passive rewarming involves external methods, while active rewarming can be either external or internal.
